Fortune may be full of fresh variety, but at Yale University it often comes with the same name: Bass.
Yesterday, for the fourth time in less than a year, a member of the Bass family of Fort Worth gave Yale a gift of $20 million.

The latest gift was made by the patriarch of the Bass family, Perry Richardson Bass, 76 years old, who graduated from Yale in 1937 with a degree in geology and who worked in the family's oil business.
The money will be used to build the Perry R. Bass Center for Molecular and Structural Biology, a 99,000-square-foot building on Yale's Science Hill that is expected to be completed by 1993.
It will house classrooms and a biophysics and biochemistry laboratory where research will be done on genetics and the role of proteins in causing AIDS, cancer and other diseases.

MAccompanied by his wife, Nancy Lee, Mr. Bass made a rare public appearance at the Yale campus to announce the gift. In the past, Bass family members have not always been present when their large gifts were made public.
"I owe this great university an enormous debt of gratitude," Mr. Bass said in a written statement.

"Fulfilling our society's demands for new scientific information about human diseases," he continued, "requires a synergistic approach, a pooling of intellectual resources that draws upon Yale's considerable strengths."

The new laboratory will focus on a process called X-ray crystallography, which produces three-dimensional computer images of protein molecules. Such information helps scientists to understand how diseases like AIDS and cancer attack the body and to design more effective medications for fighting them.
Mr. Bass is chairman and director of the Bass Enterprises Production Company and of the Sid Richardson Carbon and Gasoline Company.
In the past year, three of Mr. Bass's four sons have each donated $20 million to Yale, from which all four sons graduated.

Last May, Edward P. Bass, Class of '68, established the Yale Institute of Biospheric Studies with his gift. In October, Sid R. Bass, Class of '65, gave $20 million to support teaching and research in the humanities. On April 17, Lee M. Bass, Class of '79, endowed 11 professorships in the study of Western civilization.
A fourth son, Robert M. Bass, graduated from Yale in 1971.
